awd_titl_txt: Developing and studying the replication of Math Corps, an out-of-school-time mathematics program for urban youth
awd_abstract_narration:
The Wayne State University Math Corps is a mathematics enrichment and mentoring program that operates during summers and on Saturdays. The curriculum and the teach pedagogies in this informal learning program have documented success of supporting youths' mathematics learning as well as raising achievement levels in school. Through rigorous research and evaluation, this project seeks to analyze and understand the nature, extent, and reasons for Math Corps' success with youth learning in Detroit as well as the processes of program replication in three sites: Cleveland, OH; Utica, NY; and Philadelphia, PA. As such, this project will deepen understandings of program replication and of addressing the needs of youth in economically-challenged communities in order to promote mathematics learning.

The project's research studies will assess the multiple factors that make Math Corps successful  with youth in Detroit and document the implementation of the program to the three replication sites. Research methods include discourse analyses, surveys, interviews, and pre/post-tests. The project will also conduct a retrospective evaluation of Math Corps based on quantitative datasets regarding both near-term and long-term youth outcomes.

This projects is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understandings of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The Wayne State University Math Corps is an out-of-school mathematics and mentoring program for middle and high school students in Detroit. Founded in 1992, as a purely humanitarian effort to improve the lives of Detroit's children, the Math Corps has evolved into a highly successful STEM program, producing outstanding results and garnering national attention. In 2016, the Math Corps was recognized by the National Summer Learning Association as one of the leading summer programs in the country.

At its core, the Math Corps Summer Camp, the centerpiece of the Math Corps, is an innovative social-ethical system built on a powerful philosophy based upon "loving and believing in kids". Celebrating the individual; providing every child with a Math Corps family that includes parent figures, "big brothers" and "big sisters"; building a culture with "kindness" at its center; holding high standards and high expectations for all; seeing humor as a daily requirement; and promising a "lifetime commitment" to its kids, are some of the principles that the Math Corps combines with powerful impact. Its perspective can be seen through its 101 rules for the staff: "Believe in kids.", "Empower kids.", "Learn from kids.", "Laugh with kids.", "Lead kids.", "Be vulnerable with kids." . . . The kids have three rules: "Be yourself.", "Always strive to find your greatness.", and "Be safe." Academically, for close to thirty years, students have consistently shown dramatic gains in mathematical achievement, with pre-test averages of 30% increasing to post-test averages of 90% in six weeks. ACT math scores of Math Corps students average around 21, well above Detroit's norm. On program evaluations, about 98% of students grade the program with A's or B's.

This project had two objectives:

  1. Develop and implement a replication model of the Math Corps Summer Camp at three sites in Cleveland, OH; Philadelphia, PA and Utica, NY.
  2. Through rigorous research and evaluation, study the Math Corps and its replication, to better understand the reasons for its success and determine its replicability.

The project's outcomes and findings are summarized here:

A replication model of the Math Corps Summer Camp was developed and includes the following key elements: foundational materials describing mission and philosophy; a set of guiding principles to inform program practices; the Math Corps curriculum covering 7th-12th grade (text, lesson plans, homework, quizzes, tests, learning activities); an extensive training program that includes providing new sites with embedded staff from Detroit; and an implementation guide that provides an overview of program operations. The program was successfully implemented at Cleveland State University in Cleveland, Drexel University in Philadelphia, and Mohawk Valley Community College in Utica, NY.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The project's research and evaluation program had several components. An anthropological study, carried out over four years, used various methods to identify core elements of the Math Corps and its culture. It concluded that all three replicate sites had in fact reproduced the Math Corps' culture with a high degree of fidelity. Mathematica Policy Research conducted both retrospective and prospective studies of the Math Corps. In the key finding of its retrospective study, Mathematica concluded that the Math Corps significantly increased (with large effect) college enrollment with increased participation in the Math Corps associated with higher college graduation rates as well. According to the data, best estimates place the Math Corps' high school graduation rate at about 95%, with 90% of graduates going on to college. Mathematica also found evidence (more study is needed) suggesting that the Math Corps impacts criminal justice outcomes. According to Mathematica, "we consider the potential for a middle school summer camp to decrease criminal activity exciting."

In its prospective study, Mathematica evaluated the academic outcomes at each site and found strong results across the board in attendance, homework completion, and test scores. Students made large and statistically significant gains on the Math Corps' exam in every year of the project, with replicate site test scores rising from 38% pre-test averages to 75% post-test averages.

BROADER IMPACTS

The Math Corps has always been rooted in the cause of social justice. The results of this project show that a program with enormous impact on students from underserved communities and underrepresented minority groups, can be replicated successfully.

With broad implementation and national expansion underway (there are now new sites being developed at the University of Michigan, University of Toledo, and Spelman College in Atlanta - among others), the Math Corps will not only reach many more kids, but it will provide a model that could serve other programs and advance the field of informal (and formal) STEM learning in general.

Mathematica's findings regarding increased college enrollment point to the potential for even greater societal impacts, those associated with higher education; including better job opportunities, higher earnings, improved health, reduced crime, and the strengthening of our democracy.

 


Last Modified: 12/17/2021
Modified by: Steven M Kahn
